Derek James wrote:

>Okay, not sure "clamped" is a good word either, or that I even
>understood exactly what Ken's code was doing.
>  
>
For the record sharpneat current has min and max species parameters. The 
compatibility threshold is given an initial (user chosen) value and if 
the number of species goes outside of the min/max range then the 
threshold is adjusted up/down as necessary in order to try and get the 
species between the limits. From memory I think Ken's code I think had a 
single target '# of species' parameter, I could be wrong. I do remember 
he increased/decreased the compat. threshold in fixed increments, thus 
if the threshold was miles away from where it should be then it takes 
many generations to adjust. I tried to address this by 'accelerating' 
the movement of the threshold value, unfortunately I think this 
sometimes causes the threshold to overshoot and oscillate around a bit, 
so some minor adjustments may be necessary to 'dampen' the oscillations.

Clamp to me suggests a hard/fixed value, whereas the adjusting of the 
compatibility threshold to achieve a target # of species is a softer, 
slightly indirect way effecting the # of species. E.g. Kind of what 
might happen if the steering column in your car was made from rubber - 
the wheels /sort/ /of/ point in the direction you're indicating. 
Eventually :)

Colin.
